content.description: following the small finger crack up the arete to an easier  top out down low or finish at the top for a little harder variation
Mantle in the middle of the face in the photo. The more to the right you start the harder. Slightly easier than a V0, much easier than other V0's on this boulder.
content.location: Grab any part of the middle of the south face and mantle. Use a left heel hook.

content.description: Other than the very top of the boulder, you get exactly two holds for this problem--all other holds are off.  The first hold you get is the large, obvious jug about three-quarters of the way up the wall.  The second hold you get is the good ledge near the top of the boulder, up and right from the large jug by a foot or two.  You'll need to run and jump off the lower portion of the wall to snag the first jug.  Style points if you can grab it with only one hand while yelling, "Yeee-hawww!"  ("Cowabunga!" and "Geronimo!" are also acceptable.)
content.location: Look for the obvious jug on the face with Clay-ton and Clayface.  The stream will be mostly behind you.

content.description: SDS with good holds on same side as "clay face", climb up the center of the face on the bulge, not using the 2 jugs to copout with on clay face, you'll find the crux up high on small crimps

Per an Aaron Wilkins suggestion on the main page of this rock, this traverse begins on CLAY-ton (v1) after the first couple moves and gaining the right hand side pull, fall into a left hand pull and then reach into the diagonal crack far right. Continue the traverse on non-existent feet and top out direct or continue traversing.

The problem begins as a two hand sit start. The crux is performing the first two moves. The lack of good foot holds forces a series of quick powerful moves. The key to climbing this problem is having your feet in the right position before going for the first move.
Dead center of the boulder using side pulls and good feet to get to a couple jugs to help you top out. Love to lap this.
Start two hands on the rail with good feet, then work through a short sequence with a big power move to finish after losing your right foot.
content.location: Right side of the boulder with the stream on your left. There is a large rock on the ground to the left, your crash pad would go on the right of it. On your right side you'll have the small hill going up towards the trail.
